fields.description:
FishEye always uses the server mail address to send Notifications as it is stated in the documentation:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+SMTP

We should make this setting working with FishEye notifications too.

NB: Currently, Crucible DOES use the user's email address to send notifications.
fields.summary: Allow FishEye notification to use the user's email address when it is set in the SMTP configuration

fields.description:
In an attempt to work around the character code issue (when trying to connect FishEye/Crucible to Oracle, character set must be UTF8) is it maybe possible to have FishEye to convert the character set (whatever this is) on the fly to UTF8?

Mind you, "character conversion" is not the same as a "character set". Character conversion is the translation from one character set (e.g., UTF-16) to another character set (e.g., UTF-8).
The figure http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/server.102/b14225/ch2charset.htm#i1007338 illustrates a case where the database is using one character set, and the clients are using various other character sets with character conversion done somewhere along the way between the clients and the server.
I was wondering if such translation was possible with FishEye, so that FishEye would work even when the database is not using UTF-8.
fields.summary: Character conversion with FishEye/Crucible

fields.description:
SvnClient instances are not disposed properly after usage.

Over time this might lead to multiple DefaultSVNRepositoryPool instances accruing and occupying a chunk of memory without ever being freed.
fields.summary: SvnClient instances are not disposed() properly

fields.description:
Test instance had two repositories ('svnkit' – a copy of SVNKit and 'emtpy' – synthetic one, created for this test only) and used internal database (HSQL). Debug logging was permanently on (--Xdebug argument).

Can Atlassian document the following properties that are mentioned in the log message at startup:

{noformat}

2013-02-05 14:22:24,993 INFO  [btpool0-4 ] fisheye FishEyeSysProps-loadBooleanProperty - System property fisheye.disable.suffixpaths using value: false (default is false)

fields.description:
h5. Steps to Reproduce
# Enable Fisheye integration in your JIRA instance and connect to a local Fisheye Repository
# As an Admin user, bring up the admin search (keyboard shortcut "g+g") then search for 'Fisheye Configuration'
# Click Edit button next to the {{FishEye/Crucible Server}} hostname towards the bottom of the page
# Change 'Enable Crucible Integration' to No
# Go to 'application link' and change the {{Outgoing Authentication}} to Basic, enter credentials, and save settings
# Navigate back to Fisheye configuration 
# Click Edit button next to the {{FishEye/Crucible Server}} once again

h5. Expected Results
'Enable Crucible Integration' is still set to 'no'

h5. Actual Results
'Enable Crucible Integration' has changed back to 'yes'

(i) Using latest FeCru bundled plugin v.5.2.9
fields.summary: Modifying Incoming or Outgoing Authentication for Fisheye Crucible Application Link Automatically enables Crucible Integration Setting

fields.description:
At present, when creating a review, content can be added from all configured repositories.
This dropdown can be very slow to load for instances with a large number of repositories, even though it's truncated at 50.
It would be good to have this dropdown be restricted to/populated with only those repositories that have been linked/mapped to the Crucible project via {{Administration -> Projects -> <Crucible Project> -> Fisheye Content}}.
fields.summary: Limit the scope of 'Repository' on "Create Review" screen

fields.description:
As of 2.9.2 (FE-4357) we cache repository level permissions (can a user acces a repo). 

For LDAP specifically we could also cache LDAP query results: (LDAPAuth.doSearch). This is likely to improve performance for users using repository level LDAP permissions - often many repos share the same query, but at the moment we'll reissue it multiple times per request.
fields.summary: Using LDAP we should cache search results and not only repository permissions

fields.description:
Upgraded to FishEye 2.10.1 to get support for Mercurial 2.4 and smart commits of the form

 TKT-1 #time 0.25h This is the comment here

are broken.  This used to work (I believe we were running 2.08 previously).  See the attached e-mail alert demonstrating the problem.  Using "15m" instead of "0.25h" works fine.
fields.summary: Smart commit #time no longer supports decimal value

fields.description:
The online documentation (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+SMTP) identifies the following fields in Administration > Server > Mail Server:

|Send emails from|Select either Server address, or the User address, which selects the email address in the user's profile.
(Note: this only applies to Crucible notifications. FishEye will always use the Server Address.)|
|From Address|The from address used when FishEye sends an email, e.g. 'fisheye-noreply@example.com'|

The in-product text-field description of "From Address" appears to contradict this:

{quote}
This is the adress of the sender that will appear in emails sent by FishEye and Crucible, if you selected 'the Server address' above. {quote}
fields.summary: Align in-product text with docs RE: SMTP Server Admin

fields.description:
We are currently using FE 2.6.2
In the Administration|Security Settings, there is a page "Authentication" where one can see the Permissions Summary on all projects => this gives us the list of all projects (we have ~600 svn repositories in FE) with the authentication rights (which groups are entitled to have access to projects).

This is really helpfull to have the overview of rights and check potential gaps.

We're thinking of migrating to latest FE version, but it appears that this feature is no longer available, and the Permissions Summary is not present. 
This makes permission gaps checking impossible, as only way to see access rights is to go each project solely and click on "Permissions" tab. This is unproductive...

I wish this feature gets present again in Fisheye, as this is the only way to view overall permissions on all projects on a single page.
fields.summary: Have a summary page of authentication rights in Fisheye admin pages

fields.description:
We need a way to report to the user the current state of indexing in a more granular way than previously.

Provide mechanism to get the number of changesets in each state for a given repo.
fields.summary: provide the ability to get statistics of indexing state

fields.description:
I have made git commits (to a Stash managed repository) and Fisheye has helped put it in my activity stream. However, the commit event does not link to my user, even if JIRA, Fisheye and Stash use the same user repository. Fisheye is even capable of assigning the user in the smart commit part of it (that is, Fisheye know who closed the issue through the commit).

Similar/related to: FE-4510
fields.summary: User not linked in activity stream

fields.description:
With Fisheye, I get commits into the JIRA activity stream, but it seems like any mentioned issues don't get links there. They do get links in the Fisheye activity stream.
Maybe this is the reason for me not seeing these commits in the activity stream of the relevant project? Note that Stash has properly updated the Source tab of the issue in question.
fields.summary: Issues not linked in source tab

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Perform a lot of commits in different days to a SVN server
# View the committer history in the repo eg. http://localhost:8060/committer/svntest/klfoong
# Scroll to the bottom of the Activity Stream to load the previous commits
# Perform Step 3 for a multiple time
Only the first time is working. The second and so on will load the commit history for the current date time.

This problem does not happen if the committer is a registered user in FishEye where accessing the user history Activity Stream in a different URL eg. http://localhost:8060/user/klfoong
fields.summary: Committer Activity Stream in a repository has scrolling history update error

fields.description:
If the repository is sufficiently large and/or complex, full re-index may take days, and until it's complete, the repo will be effectively useless (new commits will not be available until the very end.)

Proposal: build a temporary index and move it into place once done.
fields.summary: Background re-indexing

fields.description:
We should immediately add validation when adding a repo to prevent creation of repos with names longer than 100 characters.

Note when trying to reproduce this: not reproducible on HSQL (possibly HSQL does not enforce length constraints).  Reproducible on postgres, not tested on others.
fields.summary: Fisheye can break quite badly if you create a repository with a long name (longer than 100 chars) and then try to add a committer mapping

fields.description:
Fisheye has a sys admin password that allows non-admin users to access the Administration section.
This can be a bit confusing to many customers as they can't clearly differentiate between a user account who is an administrator and this sys admin account. There is no documentation either to help clarify this difference.
None of the other Atlassian applications have this feature so why does FECRU need to maintain this account?
fields.summary: Remove the Fisheye sys admin password

In version 2.8 we removed "Issues" button from the UI. Please update this page:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Using+the+Dashboard

Comments are not being greyed out in some cases for cpp files.
Screenshot attached.
fields.summary: Syntax highlighting not working correctly for comments in cpp files

fields.description:
Currently a FishEye/Crucible instance can not be connected to an Oracle database that is using the "AL16UTF16" character set:

The database is not using Unicode. FishEye and Crucible require that the database uses a UTF8 encoding to support internalization." 

But AL16UTF16 is also unicode and actually support additional characters on top of UTF8
fields.summary: Support AL16UTF8 and AL16UTF16 too

fields.description:
When trying to connect to an Oracle database, I get the error message:

"The database is not using Unicode. FishEye and Crucible require that the database uses a UTF8 encoding to support internalization."

The error message should be reframed to:

"The database is not using UTF-8. FishEye and Crucible require that the database uses a UTF8 encoding to support internationalization."

if UTF-8 is the only Unicode character set allowed. And also because the word "internalization" (in the error message) is supposed to be "internationalization".
fields.summary: Update error message when connecting to Oracle database

fields.description:
The [Text file size limiting|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Text+file+size+limiting] page should be more clear regarding that the limits and log messages for size are only applied to Subversion repositories. There is no mention of this in the "Content Indexing" section.

See [FE-4498|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-4498] for reference.
fields.summary: Mention File Size Limit Settings Apply Only to Subversion Repositories

fields.description:
In FishEye/Crucible it is possible to set the file size limit to be indexed in the repositories configuration (see [screenshot|^screenshot1.png]). However, these limits are only applied to [Subversion repositories|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Text+file+size+limiting].

For example, when indexing a file around 100MB the following message is logged for a Subversion repository:
{noformat}
2013-02-13 09:45:54,319 INFO  [InitialPinger2 std-layout] fisheye RepositoryConfig-isOfIndexableSize - [std-layout] trunk/megafile.txt@36 exceeds indexing size limit (100M, limit is 5M).  The c
ontents of this files won't be searchable in FishEye or viewable in the user interface of FishEye or Crucible, and it won't count towards line of code counts.

{noformat}
While for a Git repository, nothing is logged.

In the UI, the same file can be seen in two different ways:
* [In Subversion|^screenshot2.png]
* [In Git|^screenshot3.png]

It would be more intuitive to have this option removed from the repository settings for all repositories but the Subversion ones.
fields.summary: Apply File Size Limits in DIFFS and showing Content on non-Subversion Repositories

fields.description:
With the new FishEye / JIRA integration we use a JIRA issue pattern to detect issues that have to be linked.

While this has the advantage of being very fast and not consuming a lot of resources words that are not issues can be linked mistakenly (eg: UTF-8). This is a known limitation that should be documented in the [JIRA Integration in FishEye|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/JIRA+Integration+in+FishEye] page.
fields.summary: Document the known limitation about Linked Issue in FishEye

fields.description:
I have a user whose username in JIRA/FishEye ("stefan") is different from his SVN committer name ("stefant").

Therefore, in FishEye I have created a mapping from his JIRA/FishEye username onto the SVN committer name and this mapping is correctly used within FishEye, i.e. the full/real name of the developer is shown.

In JIRA I have the "FishEye latest changesets" dashboard gadget enabled in the system dashboard.

Now, when the user "stefant" commits something then the commit is correctly shown in the latest changesets BUT the committer name is not mapped onto the JIRA/FishEye username, i.e. only "stefant" is shown and not the developer's full name.
fields.summary: FishEye user mapping not respected in JIRA's "FishEye latest changesets" dashboard gadget

fields.description:
It seems that when a user makes a Git commit, the username will be displayed as the username in Git together with <email in Git> on the Activity Stream and Source Tab without respecting the Committer Mappings in Fisheye or the Application Link Connection.

For example, the username on my Git VCS is
* username: admin
* email: immanuelsiagian@mail.com

Generally, if you are using SVN or Perforce for the source control system, only username identified in JIRA will be displayed.  

However, for Git commit only, it will display both username and email from Git.

!sourcetab.png!

!activitystream.png!

It would be great if similar behaviour for SVN is inherited similar to Git.
fields.summary: Git Commit will display username <email> from Git on the JIRA source tab

fields.description:
The following error occurred while trying to set up a remote hg repository on a fresh fecru-2.9.2 installation on FreeBSD:
{code}
2013-02-09 17:45:25,045 INFO  [InitialPinger1 ring-mvc-lastmod-bug] fisheye BaseRepositoryScanner-ping - [spring-mvc-lastmod-bug] starting initial scan of repository 
2013-02-09 17:45:25,060 INFO  [InitialPinger1 ] fisheye OneOffPingRequest-doRequest - Exception during FishEye Incremental Indexing of spring-mvc-lastmod-bug: Unable to clone remote repository: ssh://example.com/hg/projects/spring-mvc-lastmod-bug
{code}

I believe that the problem is that fecru is not forwarding its PATH environment variable when invoking hg. If hg is compiled such that the first line of its python source is using "!#/usr/bin/env python" (as a hg installed with "make local" would be), then it fails.

For reference, here is some output from "truss -eafp <fecru-java-pid>" showing that the only environment variable provided to hg is HGENCODING.
{code}
3066: chdir("/home/ecd/fecru-2.9.2/var/cache/spring-mvc-lastmod-bug/clone") = 0 (0x0)
3066: fcntl(3,F_SETFD,FD_CLOEXEC)               = 0 (0x0)
1941: _umtx_op(0x800648128,0xf,0x0,0x0,0x7ffffeff1b00,0x0) ERR#60 'Operation timed out'
1941: _umtx_op(0x800648608,0xf,0x0,0x0,0x7ffffbbbd860,0x0) ERR#60 'Operation timed out'
1941: read(528,0x7ffff9a72dec,4)                = 0 (0x0)
3066: execve("/home/ecd/bin/hg", [ "hg", "--config", "ui.verbose=false", "pull", "ssh://example.com/hg/projects/spring-mvc-lastmod-bug" ], [ "HGENCODING=US-ASCII" ]) = 0 (0x0)
3066: mmap(0x0,32768,PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE,MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANON,-1,0x0) = 34366128128 (0x800618000)
1941: close(521)        3066: issetugid(0x800818a60,0x7fffffffefcf,0x40,0x0,0xffff800800819a91,0x0) = 0 (0x0)
{code}
fields.summary: Can't clone mercurial repository if mercurial is installed such that it relies on "/usr/bin/env" to find python

fields.description:
There is an inconsistency in SVN changesets between how new files and existing files are diffed.

If the file was existing on the new branch, it shows a diff to the previous version on the branch (ie. what is being merged in).

If the file is new on the branch, it shows a diff to the version on the source branch (often "No Change") (ie. changes made _during_ the merge)

*note* behaviour is actually different for files smaller than 20 lines (the context lines) - they are displayed as full source, as the last 20 lines are considered to be the common sequence context. This is a separate issue.

Im not sure which we should be showing - what is being merged in, or the merge conflicts. But right now it is inconsistent.
fields.summary: SVN: New files merged to a branch are displayed as "No Change"

is a handy tool both for customers and Support but this doc is not available on CAC and neither has this feature been published in 2.10.1
It would be a useful tool for customers to try. I think its still in the experimental stage, but won't harm if we have a disclaimer on that CAC page.

fields.description:
If a Crucible review comment contains a text like "JA-1", it will be displayed as a "Linked Issue" under the review details, irrespective of whether this is an actual JIRA issue key or not.
Even if there is an entity link configured between a JIRA and crucible project and the propertyies "Disable for unmapped JIRA Projects" and "Force Project Mappings" has been set to "ON" in JIRA, the "Linked Issue" is still being displayed.
The actual text in the comment is also considered to be a JIRA link by default.
There appears to be no check in place to confirm the validity of the linked issue.
Screenshot attached.
fields.summary: Linked Issue does not check for invalid/non-existent JIRA issue keys

fields.description:
Prior to 2.10, this logging was appended to the console.

The log appender was added specifically for backup/restore commands so that there was some history as to when they were executed / what was happening in them.

The other commands dont really need them, and so we should only add the appender for the backup/restore commands, rather than in the log4j-client.xml which is used by all commands.

*WORKAROUND*: you can manually remove the {{name="file"}} appender from your {{log4j-client.xml}}. In addition, you also have to remove the references to the appender in the logger sections.

For example, a modified {{log4j-client.xml}} should look like this:

{code:xml}<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<!DOCTYPE log4j:configuration SYSTEM "log4j.dtd">
<log4j:configuration>
    <appender name="console" class="org.apache.log4j.ConsoleAppender">
        <param name="Target" value="System.out"/>
        <layout class="org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout">
            <param name="ConversionPattern" value="%-5p - %m%n"/>
        </layout>
    </appender>

    <logger name="org.twdata.pkgscanner">
        <level value="error" />
    </logger>

    <logger name="org.springframework">
        <level value="warn" />
    </logger>

    <logger name="com.atlassian.plugin">
        <level value="warn" />
    </logger>

    <root>
        <priority value="info" />
        <appender-ref ref="console" />
    </root>

</log4j:configuration>{code}

This will mean that backup/restore commands will only write logs to the console. (Logs generated from within FishEye core will still be logged)
fields.summary: fisheyectl commands write to log files and can throw FileNotFoundException permission denied exceptions

fields.description:
We don't do anything to validate that the entered LDAP parameters are internally consistent.  For example, a user can enter a user filter that does not select based on the UID.  This will result in a non-working LDAP configuration. See referenced SAC ticket in first comment below.

We should be able to improve this.
fields.summary: Improve LDAP configuration screen

fields.description:
SVNKit renders diffs with the file encoding specified in the 'file.encoding' FISHEYE_OPTS parameter, and UTF-8 by defualt.  This can be problematic if a repository contains mixed file encodings because when non-UTF8 files are written to a UTF-8 file the line ending character can be clobbered and the contents of the next line can end up on the current line.  This causes problems for FIshEye's diff parser because it expects the number of lines specified in the unified diff header to match the number of lines in the diff hunk.

Investigate what it will take to support mixed encoding repositories properly.
fields.summary: Properly support SVN repositories with mixed character encodings

fields.description:
Hello, I modified the file "fisheyectl.sh" and I propose the following modifications, I think it is general and it should work for everybody else (although by a quick google lookup, it seems there would some issues on MAC OS/X...(?) 

This script attempts to autodetect where the program is installed. I tried to use a two level symbolic links on this script (my setup): 

/misc/altgit/bin/fisheyectl.sh -> /misc/altgit/local/crucible/bin/fisheyectl.sh
/misc/altgit/local/crucible -> /misc/altgit/local/fecru-2.10.0

And because of these symbolic links the program stops with the following error: 

     $ ./fisheyectl.sh 
     Error: Could not find /misc/altgit/fisheyeboot.jar

The autodetection mechanism does not seems to resolve even the first link level.

As for the proposed modification, instead of (line 12-14, fisheyectl.sh) :

     FISHEYE_HOME=`dirname "$PRG"`/..
     # make it fully qualified
     FISHEYE_HOME=`cd "$FISHEYE_HOME" && pwd`

I propose :

     FISHEYE_HOME=`dirname $(readlink -e "$PRG")`/..

I could patch the file each time, but it would be appreciated if it could come right of the box. Thanks!
fields.summary: Use of readlink in starting script

fields.description:
!FishEye and Crucible Administration 2013-01-30 16-57-46 - repository defaults.png!

FishEye allows you to configure an LDAP group restriction per-repository.  We used to allow this to be set in repository defaults prior to 2.4, but when the admin was rebuilt using GWT this functionality was lost.

Note that this setting is only visible if FishEye is configured to use LDAP.  It is hdiden otherwise.
fields.summary: Configuring a default LDAP restriction did not quite make GWT-ificaiton of the admin

Issue: FE-3726
SAC ticket: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-10864
fields.summary: improve documentation for SVN symbolic rules

fields.description:
Coming from a dedicated customer:
bq. We are migrating from OnDemand shortly and we would like to have something like the application navigator in our instance.

bq. What I noticed is that Fisheye doesn't have the new header. Is there any way to add this (similar to the JIRA/Wiki)?

As seen, the Application Navigator is currently only available in [Atlassian OnDemand|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Workspace] and [Confluence 5.0|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Confluence+5.0-Beta2+Release+Notes#Confluence5.0-Beta2ReleaseNotes-Newapplicationnavigator].

I am filing this here to document it as a feature request by our customers.

{panel:title=Workaround}

{panel}

fields.description:
When using {{fisheyectl.sh}} with arguments, it does not quote those arguments when it executes its internal Java command. This means if one of your arguments contains a space, it causes FishEye to do nothing, or unexpected things.

For example, 

{code}
./fisheyectl.sh backup -f '/home/fisheye/backups/local daily backup/2013-01-25/backup.zip'
{code}

... will result in the following error -

{code}
INFO - FishEye arguments: [-f, /home/fisheye/backups/local, daily, backup/2013-01-25/backup.zip]
Usage: backup [OPTIONS]

... command description and options ...

Bad argument: daily
{code}

The fix is simple. On line 55 of {{fisheyectl.sh}}, replace {{$@}} with {{$("$@")}} and on line 57, replace {{$@}} with {{"$@"}}. (The fix for line 55 is slightly different because it is passed into another command - I haven't tested it 100% either.) By using {{"$@"}} instead, it tells the shell to quote the arguments as they were quoted when passed in before replacement.

(I'm pretty sure I've seen a bug report for this before but I can't seem to find it any more. Please mark this as a duplicate if you find it!)
fields.summary: fisheyectl.sh does not quote arguments

fields.description:
When lazy-loading directory trees we use the path hashcode as a unique id. For directories with the same hashcode this can lead to lazily loading the wrong directory.

HTR:
1. Index the attached git repo
2. Modify AbstractLazyDirTree.timeExceeded() to return true (this simulates timing out when fetching the dir tree).
3. Open the source browser
4. Try to expand the directory hashcheck/Ea

The name of the directory is replaced by hashcheck FB and the hashcheck/FB's content is shown instead of Ea's.
fields.summary: Navigating directory tree fails for lazily-loaded directories with same path hashcodes

fields.description:
As reported by a user, the activity stream on Fisheye dashboard can sometimes slow down and run in over a minute.  Looking into logs there are 3 lucene queries run by CrossRepositorySearcher#findRecentChangeSets and most often the last query is way slower than first two.

Last query is invoked by StarDownStreamActivityItemManager#hasEarlierActivity and is run to check whether there is any earlier activity on the stream to decide whether infinite scroll should attempt to bring more content.
fields.summary: Slow activity stream on Fisheye dashboard

fields.description:
see: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-31187

e.g. https://fisheye2.atlassian.com/s/1519/3/1.0/_/WEB-INF/

and https://fisheye2.atlassian.com/s/1519/3/1.0/_/WEB-INF/web.xml .

FishEye _shouldn't_ write any user data to the WEB-INF directory.

The only files which are viewable there, should be the same as those you get when you download FishEye/Crucible zip from http://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/downloads/binary/fisheye-2.9.2.zip .

fields.description:
If the browser cookies are *disabled* in order to [increase/modify the session timeout|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE027/Increasing+the+session+timeout], I cannot log into FishEye / Crucible using Google Chrome v23.0.1271.97 m neither using Mozilla Firefox v15.0.1. The dashboard can be reached, however I still see "Log In" at the top right corner.

I am able to log into the instance (and stay logged in) using Internet Explorer v9.0.8112.16421. However, I'm *never* logged out after the session timeout has been reached.

I've tried to use this configuration in {{<FECRU_INSTALL_DIR>\content\WEB-INF\web.xml}}:
{code:xml}
<session-config>
	<session-timeout>5</session-timeout>
</session-config>
{code}
Which means that the session must expire in 5 minutes.
fields.summary: Problems with browser cookies

Currently we lookup and display changeset comments in the activity stream if they exist, even if they are not enabled and there is no other way to get to them in the UI.  This can happen if changeset comments are created and then get disabled on the instance.

We should not be displaying changeset comments in the activity stream if they are disabled.

fields.description:
The bin/fisheyectl.sh script hard codes the location of JAVA_HOME.

This has changed in Mountain Lion.

See http://lists.apple.com/archives/java-dev/2011/Jul/msg00172.html for how to obtain the correct location.

bq. export JAVA_HOME=`/usr/libexec/java_home` is exactly what you want to do.
fields.summary: Use correct JAVA_HOME in fisheyectl.sh for Mac OS X

fields.description:
A customer reported that "View as patch" screen (/rdiff) can take very long time to render.  In his circumstances for a large changeset on subversion (branch creation, 44333 files, 1.2GB content) it was taking 18+ hours to render patch.

At the moment FishEye is retrieving content of both revisions (prior to the change and after change) for each individual file, comparing that and generating diff.  It could potentially utilise the information from subversion to identify this was branch creation change and run a diff only on those files which were actually changed on that changeset, ignoring files which were simply copied to the branch.
fields.summary: View as patch is slow on large changesets
Smart Commits don't work when the @username is followed by a punctuation character

fields.description:
While indexing a repository, the info message is something similar to "Committing changes {commit hash}...{commit hash} on master branch". 
This can be very misleading/confusing as it gives an impression that Fisheye is trying to make changes to the repository itself.
A better wording for this might be "Committing changes to the FishEye database: {commit hash}...{commit hash} on master branch".
fields.summary: Better messaging for "committing changes.." when indexing a repository

fields.description:
In a changeset view instead of making several parallel AJAX requests for DIFFs it maybe better to combine them into a single request for ALL files in a changeset. This would eliminate waiting time to see DIFF for next file in a changeset.

This way all other diffs from current changeset will be loaded in background while I'm viewing diff form first file in that changeset.
fields.summary: Load diffs from all files via one ajax request on changeset view
